title: russia libya putin erdogan haftar turkey middle east france italy
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Europe scrambles as Russia flexes diplomatic muscles&nbspHastily arranged peace talks brokered by Russia and Turkey have brought leaders of Libya’s two warring factions to Moscow for a surprise meeting that many hope could bring peace to the north African nation while cutting out European powers.&nbspRussian President Vladimir Putin and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan hammered out a truce leading to peace talks late last week.On Monday, just days after insisting he would not negotiate with “terrorists” in Tripoli, Libya’s renegade commander Khalifa Haftar and his adversary Fayez Serraj, prime minister of the UN-brokered Government of National Accord, met in the Russian capital for peace talks.&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlines“In line with agreements reached in Istanbul between the Russian and Turkish presidents, a Russian-Turkish meeting at the level of foreign and defence ministers on Libyan settlement has started at the Foreign Ministry’s Reception Hall,” Russian foreign ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova wrote on Facebook. “Libyan representatives have arrived and will join the talks soon.”It was a stunning and unexpected turn in the Libya conflict, and another instance of Mr Putin using the levers of diplomacy to put his imprint on the geopolitics of the Middle East and North Africa. France, Italy, Germany and other European and Arab powers scrambled to catch up. &nbsp“Until a few weeks ago the Europeans were happy of taking their sweet time,” said Jalel Harchaoui, a North Africa specialist at the Clingendael Institute, a Dutch think tank. “Now what we’re seeing is not about concrete peace as about a change of venue and the emergence of Moscow as the superpower that all the actors are happy to speak with.”Created with Sketch.Protests against Turkey sending forces to Libya Show all 12Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.A woman brandishing a rifle takes part in a demonstration held by Libyans and Syrians in the eastern Libyan city of Benghazi to protest against Turkey's prospective military interventionTurkish members of parliament vote to send Turkish troops to Libya. They passed a bill approving a military deployment to Libya aimed at shoring up the UN-backed government in Tripoli, at a time of intensifying international tensions over the conflict. The beleaguered Tripoli government has been under sustained attack since April by military strongman General Khalifa Haftar, who is backed by Turkey's regional rivals - Saudi Arabia, Egypt and the United Arab EmiratesA woman brandishing a rifle takes part in a demonstration held by Libyans and Syrians in the eastern Libyan city of Benghazi to protest against Turkey's prospective military interventionTurkish members of parliament vote to send Turkish troops to Libya. They passed a bill approving a military deployment to Libya aimed at shoring up the UN-backed government in Tripoli, at a time of intensifying international tensions over the conflict. The beleaguered Tripoli government has been under sustained attack since April by military strongman General Khalifa Haftar, who is backed by Turkey's regional rivals - Saudi Arabia, Egypt and the United Arab EmiratesMr Hafar’s Libyan National Army and forces loyal to Mr Serraj’s government have been at war over the capital, Tripoli, since April, in a conflict that has cost hundreds of lives and drawn in the interference of regional powers.&nbspMr Haftar, a former armed forces officer, launched the war promising a quick victory to his backers in Cairo and the Gulf. Both western Libyan forces rallied and prevented him from entering the capital.&nbspTurkey, a strong backer of Mr Serraj’s government, in recent weeks began to deploy troops, allied Syrian fighters, and sophisticated military hardware to Libya to counter Mr Haftar’s forces, backed by the United Arab Emirates, Egypt and Saudi Arabia.&nbspTurkey’s overt intervention and its escalating influence in Libya has prompted alarm in France and among other backers of Haftar, including eastern Mediterranean countries worried about Ankara’s attempts to lay claim to offshore gas reserves.&nbspOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailNews of the Russian and Turkish brokered talks set off a flurry of high-level diplomacy. Egypt’s President Abdel Fattah Sisi, Mr Haftar’s primary backer and mentor, conferred with German chancellor Angela Merkel over Libya.&nbspGermany now says it plans to hold long-planned Libya peace talks in Berlin on 19 January.&nbspItaly, Libya’s former colonial overlord, appeared eager to re-engage in the Libya matter after months of drifting into the orbit of France.&nbspDespite praise for the deal in the Turkish press, experts say the prospects for a lasting piece are dim. Though Mr Serraj and Mr Haftar will both be in Moscow there is no plan for the two men to meet.&nbspMr Serraj commands a measure of loyalty from the powerful armed factions that are pillars of the Government of National Accord but has little control over them. Mr Haftar could be using the peace talks to consolidate gains and buy time to rearm after his recent taking of the central Libyan city of Sirte. In the days since the ceasefire went into effect both sides have accused the other of violating its terms.&nbspTurkey sends troops and electronic warfare tools to Libya Turkey approves deployment of troops to Libya in high-stakes battleTrump will come last in the Mediterranean gas race over LibyaBy wading into Libya, Erdogan risks a major Mediterranean conflictUS military drone ‘shot down by Russian forces in Libya’Mr Haftar may have ultimately acceded to the talks under pressure from his Egyptian and Emirati backers, who were lobbied by Mr Putin. “He’s cornered,” said Mr Harchaoui. “He’s already been given far more time and resources than he initially asked for. He cannot keep asking for more time. The Emiratis know they have time to fine tune the picture later on.”Mr Putin also has a history of making flashy diplomatic announcements in order to increase Russia’s diplomatic leverage and standing, only to walk away and let others deal with the fallout when agreements flounder and the shooting resumes.&nbsp“It’s premature to talk about peace,” said Anas el-Gomati, a founder of the Sadegh Institute, a think tank focused on Libya. “The ceasefire will be temporary. It’s not designed to be operational. It’s designed for consumption. Russia is not interested in Libya. title: labour leadership clive lewis racism
story: Clive Lewis is well short of the  nominations he needs from MPs and MEPs to stay in the race beyond Monday.He said “structural racism is a reality of our society” and said the Parliamentary Labour party “isn’t immune from the same forces that affect everyone within our society”.He was speaking at the launch of his leadership campaign in Brixton, South London.Mr Lewis, the shadow economics minister, used the event to call for a referendum on the future of the Royal Family.The shadow treasury minister said: We are a democracy. I’d rather see us as citizens than subjects in the st Century.Mr Lewis called for the Royal Family referendum as part of a package of sweeping constitutional reforms, including replacing the current first past the post electoral system with proportional representation.The shadow minister also said that Labour must modernise or die.Mr Lewis said: We cant have more of the same. The Labour Party needs to modernise or it will die.Im fed up with the top-down style of politics, where real debate and discussion in our party is stled because of sectarianism and tribalism.We cant grow as a partywere afraid of having dficult discussions.Im standing because I see a party in crisis and democracy in crisis, and unless we start addressing some fundamental issues, a few tweaks of policy here, or a slight change of leader there, arent going to bring the real change that this country urgently needs.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: samira ahmed wins bbc equal pay
story: The Newswatch host was told she should have got the same as Jeremy Vine, who earned £, an episode for Points Of View.Samira, , insisted their roles were comparable — but the BBC argued it was not similar work.Yesterday, an employment tribunal ruled in favour of Samira, who earned just £ an episode, saying: “The dference in pay in this case is striking.”It said Jeremy, , just had to read from a script, adding: “If it told him to roll his eyes he did. It did not require any particular skill or experience to doBut the tribunal did not say whether Samira should get the £, she said she was owed.The ruling, following a hearing in November in London, will have major implications for BBC pay.Ms Ahmed said: “I’m now looking forward to reporting on stories and not being one.”Carrie Gracie, who quit as BBC China editor two years ago over pay, told her: “I could not be more proud of you.I hope your victory gives courage to women to stand up for the value of their work.”But the BBC insisted: “We have always believed that the pay of Samira and Jeremy Vine was not determined by their gender.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says harry meghan bankrolled
story: Their plan for global domination as Instagram’s “progressive” royal power couple looks fatally flawed.First it relies on them still being bankrolled by an increasingly enraged public — as they magnanimously “work to become financially independent” despite already being worth sums most of us cannot imagine.Second, because when they finally deem their wealth vast enough to cut that umbilical cord, their livelihood will still centre around their image as senior royals . . . a role they have quit.The idea of them busily enriching themselves by flogging their part-time royalty to advertisers will disgust taxpayers — both on principle and because this ­entitled pair will never refund a penny back into Treasury coffers.The UK public will justiably demand they be cut off at the ankles, stripped of the titles on which they trade.What then for plain Meghan and Harry Wales, the narcissist formerly known as Prince Who will listen then to their vapid sermons  They might fancy themselves as the new Clintons or Obamas — but they have not earned their  or status.They were born into it, or married into it, but gave it up when it all looked too dull, too hard and not enough fun.Diehard fans will stick by them. They will doubtless make big money. But the firestorm of criticism they have ignited here will become an inferno.It is a disastrous mess and may get worse. The couple’s assumption about the public continuing to fund round-the-clock security in Canada looks ­premature — and must be reviewed.Harry is worth £million, Meghan another £million. How much richer must they be before they pay that bill WHY is the Government still so coy about celebrating the moment of Brexit Leaving the EU at pm on January  will be a huge milestone in our modern history, the end of our -year membership and the starting gun for negotiating a lucrative new era of trade.The Sun wants Big Ben to bong. We want bunting, fireworks and, yes, commemorative Royal Mail stamps.We understand the feelings of Remainers. But there were plenty of them among the million who voted last month to “get Brexit done”.The big day is less than three weeks away following its final passage through the Commons on Thursday.How typical of Labour, given one last chance to vote for the deal securing our exit, to remain childishly opposed to it.Defeated in the referendum, crushed at the election. title: boris should not bend opinion
story: Previously, in weeks where Brexit legislation was before the Commons, discussion was dominated by whether or not the Government had the numbers to win the vote and how it should respondit did not.This time there was barely a mention of Brexit despite the votes on it this week. .Pretty much all Boris Johnson had to say on the matter was to urge ministers to, “banish Brexit”, from their lexicons after January , when the UK leaves the EU.Boris wants ministers to stop talking about Brexit once the UK has left as he doesn’t want the trade negotiations with the EU to dominate British politics in the way that leaving has since the referendum. He wants to show voters that the country has moved on and the Government is once more focusing on the domestic issues voters care about.But however much he tries, it will be hard to make these talks boring. They are important and there is already DRAMA BREWING.Boris saw the new Commission President Ursula von der Leyen in Downing Street this week. The pair got on well in their hour-long meeting. They both want these talks to be less acrimonious than the orce negotiations both want a more cordial tone.The pair reminisced about the school they had both attended in Brussels. Unlike Eton, it didn’t have playing fields, and until Johnson arrived the only game in the playground was marbles. He introduced some more rough and tumble.No were pleased that von der Leyen, rather than the more confrontational Michel Barnier, took the lead. As one No source points out, the EU loathed the lack of clarity and authority under Theresa May: She wasn’t clear what she wanted and it wasn’t certain that she could deliver what she wanted.With Boris and his new majority it is very dferent. He was able to point von der Leyen to the Tory manesto’s commitments on the future trade deal and say this was his mandate and that he was determined to deliver it.Yet despite the pair’s attempt to maintain a friendly tone, there are already tensions. Boris is irritated that the EU keeps saying it is nigh-on impossible to negotiate a full trade deal by December , despite having signed up to a political declaration that commits it to trying to do just that.The DANGER is that the EU thinks that under time pressure Boris will bend, that he will either extend the transition period — something he has repeatedly promised not to do — or drop his commitment to breaking away from EU rules and regulations.Boris is determined not to do either of these things. He doesn’t want to extend and believes in the value of the UK having the right to do things dferently.Both sides have frequently misunderstood each other in this process. Both sides must now realise that the other means what it says. Unless they do, there is going to be an almighty bust-up and no trade deal at the end of all this.THERE will be a National Security Council meeting later this month to decide whether or not to allow the Chinese company Huawei to be involved in the construction of the UK’s G network.This is an issue of fierce debate in Whitehall. Under Theresa May, it led to the then Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson’s sacking from government.Hawkish figures inside government fear No is leaning towards allowing Huawei’s involvement. One complains that Downing Street’s timetable for the technology’s roll-out is, “not realistic”, but that this time pressure means it will need Huawei involved. However, I understand that the Americans are pushing very hard for the UK to bar Huawei.One senior US government national security figure has been in London this week to lobby directly on this point.Before he makes a decision on Huawei, Boris Johnson should consider the damage it could do to Britain’s most important security relationship – the Five Eyes intelligence-sharing agreement with Australia, Canada, the US and New Zealand.Eventhe UK thinks it can manage Huawei’s involvement,our allies do not then we shouldn’t proceed. It is simply not worth the risk of undermining such a vital alliance.Don’t expect his approach to change. His holidays will be far more glam than Cameron and May’s were.THE most common reason British governments fail is that the Prime Minister and the Chancellor fall out.If No and the Treasury – the most powerful department in government – aren’t on the same page, nothing gets done.Boris Johnson and Sajid Javid are determined to avoid this fate. In the run-up to the Budget on March , there will be a huge effort to make sure that the Treasury and No work together.One Johnson ally tells me the two men will have a Budget-focused meeting at the start of each week to make sure they are in agreement on the key issues.Then their teams will meet again mid-week to assess progress. Javid, whose job is safe in the coming reshuffle, is determined to show that the Treasury is capable of delivering on Boris Johnson’s agenda of levelling up across the country.Those close to him are confident that they can put meat on the bones of No’s plan.AT Cabinet this week it was impressed on ministers that one of the most important events this year is COP, the climate change conference the UK is hosting in Glasgow in November.The UK Government wants to use the event to show how Britain can lead on clean growth post-Brexit.I understand there will be a steady drum beat of announcements on this front throughout the year: The Tories want to show they are helping create new green-collar jobs.They also hope that by holding the event in Scotland, they can emphasise the benefits of the Union.THE Labour leadership contest has yet to catch fire.The Tories are not particularly concerned about any of the candidates.Though there is some hesitation about how they would handle PMQs with Jess Phillips, who likes to make very personal attacks on Boris Johnson.But the most interesting candidate in the race is Lisa Nandy.She seems to have the clearest understanding of why Labour lost.Her bid is starting to have faint echoes of David Cameron’s successful tilt at the Tory leadership in .GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: queen landmark meeting heated atmosphere
story: To my knowledge, something like this has never happened before in terms of what it is all about and that it is happening so quickly.This is the ultimate summit between the head of state, the two heirs to the head of state and the sixth in line to the throne.With Charles and Diana’s orce, the Queen wrote to them inidually saying they had to start talking and sort orce proceedings. She didn’t meet them.Even the abdication of Edward VIII over Mrs Simpson, together below, was at Government and Church level.To have documents prepared in advance does not surprise me. The Queen has said she wants this sorted out and without delay.Many have called this an abdication and in one sense it is. Harry and Meghan expect to still have a handle on royal duty but also to lead a private le.What they mean by living financially independent, I don’t know. They aren’t financially independent now — they get £.- million from the Prince Of Wales and about five per cent from the Sovereign Grant.Harry is reasonably wealthy but not necessarily in cash flow. The sums he inherited from his mother and great grandmother have been invested.Meghan has some means but to live the sort of lestyle they are used to takes a lot of money.It is conceivable Charles could cut the money he gives to Harry —he gives him any at all. Being a dad, he probably will.But there are tax implications — particularlythere are handouts.Security has also to be considered. Harry is a prince of the United Kingdom, his grandmother head of state and father heir.The atmosphere at the meeting will be, up to a point, heated. But people won’t lose their tempers.The Queen is pragmatic. She understands problems people have but Harry will be fully aware of her displeasure. To go off half-cocked as he and Meghan did is unacceptable.The question is how dare they do that. She signed up for this. So what’s changed their minds I’d love to be a fly on the wall of the events in that meeting . . . provided no one has a fly swat!Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: see back of harry and meghan
story: What a waste of the mountain of goodwill there was towards that happy, glamorous couple who wed on a sunshine-soaked day in Windsor in . And what a waste of their chance to play a key role in helping our Royal Family prosper after the Queen is gone.And what a waste of Harry and Meghan’s unique chance to be a living, inspirational representation of the multiracial country in which we now live. How quickly the shine has come off the golden couple.Less than two years after that wedding day, Harry and Meghan are scurrying off to an ill-defined “progressive” new le in Canada.Butthey have been unhappy with their royal roles, they have brought it on themselves. This much-loved couple have always been too thin-skinned for their own good.They have always been hysterically touchy when justied criticism came their way, such as when they lectured about climate change while reclining on private jets.The criticism was nothing personal. Hollywood stars get called out for climate hypocrisy. Do Harry and Meghan really imagine we will just tug our forelocks as they fly around the world in private jets while talking like Greta Thunberg in a tiara Harry and Meghan are never satisfied with anything less than unconditional deference. They apparently loathe royal le, yet demand to be treated like royalty.They have demonstrated an epic sense of entitlement, such as asking the taxpayer to pick up the £.million builder’s bill for doing up their home, Frogmore Cottage.Their great self-pitying delusion is that the wicked British media has it in for them. But it is not the media that caused Meghan so much excruciating embarrassment.It is largely her own dysal family and their indiscreetly flapping cakeholes, especially her dear old discarded dad Thomas Markle and her loony half-sister Samantha. Harry and Meghan’s self-pity is astounding.“Never complain, never explain,” has been the motto of the modern Royal Family. It has worked rather well.But place Harry and Meghan in front of a sympathetic camera crew, such as when ITV’s Tom Bradby trailed them on their tour of South Africa, and they can’t stop whining. Even when surrounded by victims of rape and landmines, they managed to feel sorry for themselves.“Not many people askedI’m OK,” Meghan complained in the Third World. There has not been a royal couple with such a staggering lack of self-awareness since Marie Antoinette and King Louis XVI of France. And look what happened to them.Harry and Meghan owe their mega-celebrity totally to their connection with the Royal Family. Their superstardom has nothing to do with Meghan’s acting career. Their lives of unimaginable luxury are funded in large part by the British taxpayer.The average couple spends just under £, on their wedding. Harry and Meghan were said to have blown £MILLION. Yet they do not appear to have a grateful bone between them. They seem incapable of counting their multiple blessings.Even now, after handing in their royal resignation, they give every indication that they want all the privileges of royal le with none of the obligations. They want to have their Eton mess and eat it.Harry and Meghan’s security alone currently costs around £, a year, paid for by the politan Police — which means paid for by the British taxpayer. Get the Mounties to start paying for it.And can we finally nail the great lie that Meghan has been persecuted in the UK because of her mixed race  When she first appeared, Meghan was a hurricane of fresh air. The British looked at her and it was love at first sight.This weary, ided, Brexit-battered nation was delighted to have an injection of Hollywood glamour. And millions of Brits now live in mixed-race families. There was real delight to see the Royal Family catching up with the rest of us.Among those crowds at Windsor on their wedding day I saw families of every race and creed under the sun who were ecstatic to see the Royal Family becoming less white, more inclusive, more representative.Harry and Meghan have drawn criticism because of their total lack of self-awareness. Both of them are independently rich. Harry is worth around £million after inheritances from his mother and the Queen Mum.Prince Charles gives him £million every year. Meghan made around £million from her role in long-runningTV legal drama Suits.Yet this fabulously wealthy couple have been happy to let others — the British taxpayer, Prince Charles, the Queen — pay their way in their gilded world.Six weeks, which is theof time that Harry and Meghan have just spent in Canada, is a very long time to be away from home.Unless, of course, “home” doesn’t feel like home because you feel criticised for everything you do and wear, your family – on both sides – are a nightmare and you are constantly judgedby people who have never met you and never will.I should imagine that in this case, Canada seems like a very good place to call home. So, who can blame Meghan and Harry for deciding to leave the UK behind to get away from it all, and maybe staying away from here in the long-term I have a lot of respect for the couple for ploughing their own furrow and walking their own path.Honestly, I couldn’t be happier for Harry, who has experienced so much sadness, that he has met a woman brave enough to suggest doing things a bit dferently.Although they are currently making bold statements about giving up the taxpayer-funded Sovereign Grant, they show no sign of being willing to pay for their own security, or their own flunkies, or offer the taxpayer a rebate on those reported £million nuptials.There has never been even the slightest hint of gratitude. There has never been any indication that they — this rich, pampered couple with a beautul baby boy who will never want for anything — realise how lucky they are.So Harry and Meghan are not the only ones with mixed emotions today. There is real resentment that Harry and Meghan have caused distress to our Queen and it will not be easily forgotten or forgiven.The Queen has a -year-old husband who has recently been in hospital. title: blind eye iran no longer option
story: No president could ignore the killing of US contractors, the invasion of its embassy in Baghdad, the threat to the lives of American service personnel.If that threat was imminent, he was right to act. We would have done the same to protect British servicemen and women. In fact, as Britain’s Defence Secretary I did exactly that, with the full support of Prime Minister David Cameron.Let’s not forget that every country has the right to self-defence.Of course, nobody wants this crisis to escalate. Indeed Iran’s retaliation has been noticeably limited so far.But the chorus for “de-escalation” carries risks too. Iran has been attacking Western shipping, including capturing a British tanker. Iran has fired missiles at Saudi oil refineries.Iran continues to wage proxy wars in Lebanon, Syria and Yemen. Through its militias, Iran continues to destabilise neighbouring Iraq.At some point, somebody had to draw the line. Qasem Soleimani was no hero or statesman. He directed terrorist attacks across the Middle East.Thousands of Syrians, Iraqis and Yemenis died as a result. Iranian dissidents, too, were brutally suppressed.The roadside bomb-making he sponsored killed many of our brave servicemen in Iraq. As Prime Minister Boris Johnson reminded us, he had the blood of our soldiers on his hands.Has Trump’s strike weakened the case for Western intervention  It is worth remembering our troops and those of the US are in Iraq at Iraq’s invitation.Since , we have helped lead an international coalition of more than  countries to support its fragile democracy and liberate that country from the terrorist death-cult of Daesh Isis.And thanks to precision strikes by the RAF and the training by the British Army of thousands of Iraqi troops, Daesh has lost the pernicious grip it once had.Defeating Daesh isn’t just a matter of helping a friend in need or of standing up for human rights. Mercully, we have stopped Yazidi women from being raped, prisoners being burnt alive, gay people being thrown off buildings and Western hostages sadistically executed.But tackling Daesh terrorism is also vital to protect our own way of le here in Western Europe.Islamist fundamentalism needs to be defeated, whether in Mosul, Raqqa, a Paris suburb or on London Bridge.So yes, let’s continue to work with our allies to persuade Iran’s revolutionaries to take a dferent path.Saudi Arabia, the other Gulf countries and even Russia all have roles to play in getting Iran back to the negotiating table.After the appalling shooting down of the Ukrainian airliner, let’s try to show the Iranian people their government needs to be more truthful and more open, that there is a better future beyond the mullahs and the republican guards.But diplomacy alone will not be enough. We have to protect our national interests too. Trump’s strike is a stark reminder that in the end, we must all stand up when those interests are threatened so directly.First, we must persuade other European navies to work with the US and our own Royal Navy in patrolling and protecting convoys through the Strait of Hormuz.This is a vital choke point for Europe’s trade and energy. The gas and oil we need this winter pass through it.It is ludicrous that some Nato allies won’t work with American ships for fear of upsetting the mullahs in Tehran.This has to be a US-led international operation.Second, we need a better nuclear agreement with Iran. It was right to try to halt their nuclear programme. But the previous deal wasn’t comprehensive — it didn’t even cover missiles — and it completely failed to constrain Iranian misbehaviour in the region. If anything, Iran used the access to new finance that deal released to step up its proxy wars in Yemen and where.A new deal should ensure full oversight of all Iran’s nuclear activities by the International Atomic Energy Agency, and only allow Iran back into the international markets when its civil nuclear programme is in complete compliance.Third, we have to step up our campaign against terrorism.Outside the EU after Brexit, we will still need to share intelligence and work together with our European partners to identy new attacks. But our closest ally in the battle to protect our values will always be the US. We may not always agree with Trump’s tactics but we shouldn’t ignore that he has finally cut through the illusion — Iran’s current regime is not our friend.Iran will certainly have learned a lesson from President Trump’s decisive action. But I hope we will do so too.Turning a blind eye to those who foster international terrorism is no longer an option for any of us.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what you do after mistakes important
story: But in all honesty, what really matters is not so much what happened but how we respond.Take the young woman who was in court this week after drunkenly propositioning male passengers on a flight from Abu Dhabi to Manchester. She askedthey wanted to join her in the “mile-high club”, then attacked cabin crew who refused her more alcohol.Demi Burton tried to headbutt and kick six crew members and passengers who tried to restrain her before she was arrested when the plane landed.In court, the -year-old claimed she had been drinking because she has a fear of flying and said this behaviour is out of character, which may be true.Her defence lawyer Martin Callery said: “She is thoroughly ashamed of herself . . .  and utterly embarrassed at the way she behaved.”But that is certainly not the impression she conveyed outside court, where she gleefully flicked obscene hand gestures at photographers.No doubt she stopped smiling when she heard she had been sentenced to six months in prison. Personally, I’m not sure how effective prison is. But the problem with reckless behaviour is that you have to face the consequences.And I really hope for Demi, this is the moment she gets her le back on track. We all make mistakes. It’s what we do afterwards that defines us.It would be easy to assume that Demi is a hopeless case. But she is young enough to turn her le around, to work hard, do better and see this rock-bottom moment as a catalyst for change.And then something good will come from what is a very low moment in her le. We don’t have to look far for examples of people who have overcome lapses or mistakes before going on to succeed.Take Robert Downey Jr, who went from drug addict to one of Hollywood’s highest-paid actors. Or Elton John and Robbie Williams, both of whom have overcome major drug issues before enjoying renewed stardom, fatherhood and, more importantly, a good le.While it is not the same as a drunken mistake, anyone who has made it in business will have a good few failures under their belt — whether it is a dodgy commercial decision, plain bad luck or a company that has gone bust.It is not what happens to us in le but what we do next that counts. So I am guessing that, from her cell, Demi might be reflecting on what she might do dferently when she gets out. Andshe isn’t, she should be.Because it is the getting back on the horse that counts, evenit means resisting the urge to go back to bed to hide. No one is perfect. No one gets through le without messing up or things going wrong.Before success, you will get temporary defeat or total failure. The key to getting through it is resilience. And one of the best gts you can give a child is to encourage them not to give up.By the way, I speak here from experience. Like any businesswoman, I’ve made some mistakes and had my fair share of knocks.There are some that I have managed to turn to my advantage and others that I have had to chalk up to experience.The key thing is that I have learned from what went wrong, then moved on. That experience has allowed me to create a mini-manesto on how to fail how to respond to setbacks and failure, which I’ll share here now:Give yourself time to recover and reflect. Force yourself to take small steps to get back on the horse. Do not accept failure. See it as a step on the journey towards success.Remember that challenging and dficult moments are what help you grow bigger or better. Without them, you would stay the same.The only people who haven’t experienced setbacks are people who are too scared to try. So “failure” is often a sign of bravery. Hold your head up high at all times.Try your best and be proud to do so, eventhings don’t always work out the way you want them to. Remind yourself: “Where there is a will, there’s a way.” And as they say, the best thing about the future is it comes one day at a time.ANOTHER new year, another month of looking at photos of scantily clad people on beaches in sunnier climes and asking myselfI am the only person who is not on the beach.This is the time of year for massive bikini-body and holiday FOMO.But let us all take heart that it is also, oh joy, the time of year for elasticated waists hidden under chunky knitwear.Personally, I am more than happy to swap the beach for nothing to shave and no stomach to suck in. Bliss.I’M sure parents everywhere were shocked to read the story of the son who bullied his mother and stepfather so viciously he has been jailed for three years for his controlling and coercive behaviour.When Nicholas Hazell, , of County Durham, went back to live with Judith Ridley, , and her reverend husband Stephen, , after losing his job, he made their lives hell.Hazell, above, created a “horrendous atmosphere” at the family home and flew into a petulant ragehe didn’t get his own way, Durham Crown Court heard.Among his worst outbursts were when Hazell threw his mother into a chair and spat at her while holding a screwdriver to his stepfather’s throat. He also told them: “I am a master of bullying.”It sounds horric.I feel so sorry for his mum, who must be devastated that her little boy turned into a cruel bully as an adult.I dont do needles when it comes to my face.  Lasers, facials, peels . . .  sure. But needles are another story entirely.If you are willing to take the chance of injecting poison into your face, at the very least you want a predictable result. And in my experience, you don’t get it.Who wants eyebrows at the top of their head, lips that come into the room before you do, or a forehead that doesn’t move  Not me, that’s for sure. However . . .This week I read that not only is the gorgeous Abbey Clancy having micro-Botox injections, hyaluronic acid fillers and vitamins, she is doing it with TWENTY needles at once.Abbey, , is having something called an aquagold facial, so called because each needle is covered in -carat gold. The marketing blurb claims this treatment will reduce pores, blur out fine lines and leave your skin with a vibrant glow.Some might say this is a slippery slope to the stronger stuff but Abbey looks amazing.  So it has to be worth a try, don’t you think I HAD to laugh at the photos of the BBC newsreader whose dress, which had burst open minutes before going on air, was cobbled together from behind by quick-thinking colleagues.  Liz Beacon’s outfit was patched up with gaffer tape and bulldog clips.I used to believe what I saw on TV. But since filming The Apprentice, I know all too well that all is not necessarily what it seems.Two examples spring to mind. First, the countless times I have been filmed in the boardroom with a smart jacket on top and leggings or even pyjama bottoms and slippers under the boardroom table.Second, and worse, the time I somehow forgot to bring a bra on a day I was wearing a white blouse.Luckily, a kind crew member who is roughly the same size as me lent me hers.  And the show, as it always seems to do, went on.I WAS appalled to read about the private Islamic secondary school that has been “unlawfully segregating” boys and girls for all activities except weekly assemblies, according to a stinging Ofsted report.One of the teachers theretold pupils “university is not for females”, according to the report. Which begs the question of where, then, is the best place for females  The kitchen Inspectors who visited Birmingham’s Redstone Educational Academy in November last year also found male students were given privileges and treated more favourably than their female counterparts when it came to sports, school trips and work experience.That was something disputed by the headteacher.That’s not good enough. There can be no place for a school like this and it should be closed down.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour contender clive lewis sparks outcry after claiming brexit vote had racism at its core
story: The Norwich South MP said non-white Britons woke up with a “sense of dread” the day after the referendum, which will see Britain finally leave on January .Having previously suggested racism was a reason some Labour MPs were not backing him, the arch-Remainer now also claimed it was integral to Brexit.He said: “I think part of the Brexit campaign, and part of the undertone of Brexit, from some politicians, Nigel Farage and others, had racism at its core and its heart.“They used it as a mechanism to ide our communities, to ide our country.“How many people of colour, how many people of colour, on the day after the referendum with a sense of dread because of what had happened “Ultimately our country had chosen to listen to Boris Johnson, someone who has a track record of racist commentary, of giving credence to racism.”Despite his bizarre claims, the leadership hopeful admitted some of his own family voted to leave the EU.He said: Now that doesn’t mean that every single person that voted for Brexit is a racist, some of my family voted for Brexit but I think there were drivers within that campaign that certainly were very unsavoury and what I would call racist.”The radical leftie also called for the Royal Family and private schools to be abolished.His comments sparked fury among Brexiteers, with Sir Iain Duncan Smith labelling them “breathtaking absurdity”.He said: “He’s saying this about . million people.“The present Labour party does not understand why people have turned away from them.“The Labour party think they won the election but were finally let down by the British people at the end.”Passionate Brexiteer Steve Baker also blasted the leadership contenders claims.He said: “Clive’s hysterics are not just wrong, they obviously didn’t work with the British public, who are far too sensible for this rubbish.“It’s time to pull together, not sow more ision.”

title: michael fabricant letter to queen
story: In his letter to Her Majesty, Michael Fabricant says Buckingham Palace’s dilemma over what to do with Prince Harry “could be turned into a huge triumphthey accept his proposal.And the MP says that far from being “a cause for sorrow,” the decision by Harry and Meghan to quit the Firm and relocate to Canada could instead be “a wonderful opportunity for both the Royal Family and our country European Union”.He points to a poll that found six in ten Canadians were in favour of Prince Harry becoming Governor General of Canada.Mr Fabricant says Prince Harry would be “well-suited to this works, give him more than enough experience to serve as Your Majestys representative to Canada.”As Your Majesty will no doubt be aware, the decision by the Duke and Duchess of Sussex to step back from their royal duties to spend more time in North America has caused quite a stir among your loyal subjects.While many disapprove of this, may I make the case that this can in fact be a wonderful A recent Postmedia poll in Canada found that over % there were in favour of Prince Harry becoming the Governor General of Canada.The poll also showed that it was younger Canadians who would be most in favour of such a move, and that even in the generally French republican province of Quebec, almost half would also support this.The current Governor General, Julie Payette, who has been in post since , has done a sterling job. However, neither she, nor anyone  who has previously held this position, possess the same kind of box office appeal that Harry does.While their methods and approach to royal duties may not always fall in line with tradition, there is no doubting that Harry and Meghan are seen by many of the younger generation as symbols of a new, modern, vibrant monarchy.Installing Harry as Governor General would not only bolster support for the Monarchy internationally, but also provide Canada, and by extension the United Kingdom, an enormous boost in soft power at an important juncture for our country as we depart the European Union.Procedurally, there would be few barriers to making this a reality. title: keir starmer posh remainer leader
story: It was this “Posh Trot” Remainer who drove a bulldozer through Labour’s so-called Red Wall and cleared the path for Boris Johnson’s invasion of its northern heartlands.It was Starmer’s campaign for a chaotic second referendum that persuaded millions of working-class supporters to vote Tory for the first time and condemn Labour to the political wilderness.Not surprisingly, Starmer’s critics now wonder why this proven loser is in pole position to run their party.Some point the finger at Gordon Brown quietly rallying supporters to the cause.The ex-PM and his protegé have been close since Starmer’s controversial reign as Director of Public Prosecutions from  to .Starmer, despite his reputation for defending human rights, is not above sly ploys.There is nothing wrong with being wealthy — except among the Momentum voters he needs to seize Labour’s crown. Perhaps this explains why his Wikipedia entry has just been doctored to delete his status as a “millionaire”. Not me, guv, protests Starmer.He is also weirdly reluctant to declare where he stands on the political spectrum. Is he a Corbynite or a Blairite or a bit of both  “I don’t have the names of former leaders tattooed on my head,” snfs the man named at birth after the first leader of the Labour Party.This knight of the realm, who played violin at fee-paying Reigate Grammar School alongside Fatboy Slim, claims a humble background as the son of a toolmaker.“I know what it’s like,” he insists, asraised in a cardboard box.Well, I went to the same school when it was a “bog-standard” state grammar. My father was a journeyman upholsterer. It didn’t give me any special insights.Starmer boasts in his new campaign video about picket-line stints alongside down- trodden Wapping printworkers — against my boss, Rupert Murdoch, a hate figure on the Left.This chameleon politician was dubbed a “Sir” on the recommendation of Gordon Brown, a title he discourteously declines to use because it invites contempt among those with a vote.His citation was for “services to law and criminal justice”, after a five-year term as DPP.At about the same time he was parachuted into Parliament as MP for rock-solid Labour Holborn and St Pancras, in London.It is here that self-respecting Labour voters should pause and reflect.Many believe these political plums were reward for the longest, costliest and perhaps most spiteful criminal persecution in history — ordered by Sir Keir Starmer.His new leadership video slyly refers to this time, apparently to boost his scourge-of-capitalism image among the “comrades” — even though politics should play no part in a DPP’s decision-making. In a travesty of justice, he rammed two dozen innocent journalists through Old Bailey trials on trumped-up conspiracy charges — a medieval catch-all which even the Crown Prosecution Service admitted was “an extremely dficult and rarely visited area of the law”.The prosecuting counsel was given a flea in his ear for “chopping and changing”, the charges against the journalists.The trials ended with acquittals all round, an admission that “no crime may have been committed” and this rebuke from the Lord Chief Justice:“What concerns me is the freedom of the Press and the desire of officials to contain information.“We must ensure the Press is protected — we can’t use criminal sanctions to undermine their position.”The defendants were all journalists on The Sun or the News of the World — then seen by the Left as fair game.The trials followed The Sun’s decision to switch its support from Gordon Brown’s floundering regime to David Cameron’s Tories.Some believe the two were linked — but surely that’s just a conspiracy theory.What is absolutely clear to those who care about the issue is Starmer’s readiness to use his power to curb Press freedom.As citizens of totalitarian regimes rapidly learn to their cost, without a free Press there is no such thing as free speech.IT’S win-win for the Sussexes and losses all round for the House of Windsor.Meghan’s first kiss-and-tell will be a bestseller, with all the gossip on Randy Andy and those secret royal scandals.Harry’s right-on charities will be milked for millions.Once our revered Queen has departed, the monarchy will dwindle to a sideshow on the US celebrity circuit.Charles is too old to compete and William is too dull, despite Kate’s best efforts.Hero Harry will emerge as victor in this grotesque civil war. revealed that Debenhams was set to close  of its stores.But  stores have been confirmed to shut in the next three weeks, including Altrincham, Wolverhampton, Ashford and Wimbledon.Heres the full list of closures announced so far:Its believed to be a combination of increasing rents, business rates and a rise in online shopping.Richard Lim of Retail Economics, told the BBC in October  that Debenhams is operating in the part of the market under the most intense amount of pressure.He said: Put simply, department stores are incredibly expensive to run.The combination of too much space, inflexible leases and spiralling operating costs are set against a backdrop an accelerating behavioural sht towards online and experiences.This is eroding their profitability and changes in the business need to occur at a pacethey are to survive.Speaking at the time, Debenhams executive chairman Terry Duddy said: Debenhams has a clear strategy and a bright future, but in order for the business to prosper, we need to restructure the groups store portfolio and its balance sheet, which are not appropriate for todays much changed retail environment.Our priority is to save as many stores and as many jobs as we can, while making the business fit for the future.The retailer, which employs , staff, is now in the hand of lenders as part of this process.They took control of the struggling retailer which wiped out the investments of shareholders, including Sports Direct billionaire Mike Ashley.It would have seen Debenhams lenders agree to write off £million of its £million debts, which the retailer said was not sufficient.Instead, it has chosen to implement a pre-pack administrationThis is an insolvency process for a business to sell its assets before appointing administrations.It is a powerful way of selling on a business to a third part of buyer.The deal doesnt mean that Debenhams will disappear from the high street but some stores will still close.Customers are still able to spend their gt cards as stores will continue to trade as normal.However shoppers have been urged to use any gt cards they have while the retailer is still accepting them.Gt cards, orders and s are still being accepted as usual.MoneySavingExpert founder Martin Lewis warned shoppers not to buy any new gt cards from the retailer.He said: Clearly, Debenhams is not in the most stable state at the moment. So personally I wouldnt be buying anyone any gt vouchers from there in the future.Mr Lewis also says shoppers should be careful about what they order or buy from the retailer and recommends they make purchases on card so theyre protectedsomething goes wrong.

title: uk weather forecast 80mph storm brendan
story: A double “weather bomb” is set to leave a trail of disruption with hurricane-force gales, ft waves, floods and snow.Met Office forecaster Marco Petagna said: “Storm Brendan brings risks of short-term power loss and transport delays, with gusts up to mph locally in the North-West.Thursday sees another system with potential for severe gales similar in strength to Tuesdays gusts, with the West including Scotland most at risk.The torment is a double weather bomb because the Met Office forecasts showed the storm is strengthening as its air pressure plunges by around  millibars in  hours - double the  millibars needed to qualy as a weather bomb.The Met Office has issued a yellow weather warning for high winds across the west, south-west and north-east of the country between am and midnight on Monday.While the North East of Scotland is expect to be hit from lunch time today to midnight tomorrow.This morning  more than  homes were blacked out after electricity failures near Falmouth and Truro in Cornwall as the winds began bringing trees down across cables.There are also warnings of potential flooding caused by heavy showers of torrential rain.Blustery conditions are already causing trouble in the North East with an Easyjet flight erted from Newcastle to Edinburgh Airport.Film captured on Saturday showed at least two ersions, with one Jet Boeing - having to perform a go-around as the wind hit mph.Easyjets flight from Malaga had to pull up at the last minute as a gust threatened to destabilise its landing.After four attempts it was erted to Edinburgh. A Jet flight was also erted to Manchester.Ireland is already dealing with the consequences of Storm Brendan with at least  homes in County Cork affected by power cuts as of this morning.Yesterday it was a reported that a man had been swept out to sea by large waves on the Blackpool seafront as the country braces for strong winds from Storm Brendan.Concerns were raised late on Saturday by a member of the public after they looked down from the promenade and saw a man on the beach very close to the water.HM Coastguard launched an intensive search but no trace of anyone was found.RAC spokesman Simon Williams told people to take extra care as , RAC call-outs are expected today.He said: Dont get caught by one of winters fiercest storms so far.

title: dawn butler deputy labour diverse
story: NewsopinionDawn Butler: This could be the most erse contest yet but MPs must put me on the ballot firstEXCLUSIVE The shadow women and equalities secretary is currently seven short of the nominations she needs to get through to the next stage of the Deputy Labour leadership electionShareCommentsByDawn Butler:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsopinionDawn Butler needs more nominations to get on the ballot paper " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDo you know why black people do better in sports than they do anywhere  ” the US civil rights leader, Jesse Jackson, once asked. “Because the playing field is even and the rules are public. So we can compete. But when the field is tilted and people start making up the rules … thataposs when the problems start. Last week, as Samira Ahmed won her equal pay claim against the BBC, we saw just how the game is rigged. Ahmed, who hosts the viewer feedback programme, Newswatch, was paid seven times less than Jeremy Vine, who presents a similar programme, Points of View. Seven Times! The BBC justied this discrepancy by claiming that the Points of View needed a “cheeky” presenter with a “glint in his eye”. That’s some glint! The BBC clearly knew what they meant. They paid enough for it, I on the other hand wasn’t so sure. But when subjected to the critical eye of an impartial jury the rationale clearly fell apart. “Jeremy Vine read the script from the autocue,” their devastating assessment read. “He read it in the tone in which it was written. If it told him to roll his eyes, he did. It did not require any particular skill or experience to do that….We have dficulty in understanding what [the BBC] meant by a ‘glint in the eye’ and how that translated into a ‘skill’ or ‘experience’ for the job.  How does one acquire such a skill or experience ” The point here is not to do down Jeremy Vine. I like him and his competence was not on trial.  His pay is not going down. It is to try and decipher why a woman would be paid so much less for essentially the same work. How could Ahmed’s talents be so undervalued  How could her talents be so invisible  What were they thinking  How could this happen  As the shadow minister for equalities I know nobody in the BBC was sitting there thinking - “How can we pay a woman less than a white man for the same job ” This was not a deliberate ploy. Discrimination, nowadays, rarely works like that. True, there are people who think little of women and denigrate people of colour. One of them lives at Number . Imagine how the media would have treated meI had been caught having three affairs, one love child,  refused to tell anyone how many children I had and talked about white people the way Boris Johnson has talked about black people and Muslims. But beyond that gilded world, where a pliant media look past the prejudice of the privileged, many of us work in institutions that simply haven’t caught up with how the way the world has changed. They are driven by the same impulses and reflexes as they were when women were supposed to stop working once they had kids and black people were rarely seen and never heard. Ahmed was effectively caught in a system that devalues women and people of colour, failing to see their potential and to understand their contributions as valid.  We are judged by dferent standards. The verdict could leave the BBC with a bill running into the millions as similar claims by other female staff now come to the fore. But the cost to their reputation. This is the nation’s broadcaster. People expect more from the BBC. Ahmed certainly did. The bravery and tenacity it took for her to pursue this course of action cannot be underestimated. “I love working for the BBC,” she said.  “No woman wants to have to take action against their own employer.” Tomorrow I hope to make it onto the ballot for the Labour Party Deputy Leadership.  tle I’m certainly qualied. I’m the first elected black woman in Britain to ever become a minister I’ve had responsibilities under two Labour prime ministers Tony Blair and Gordon Brown and I have served in Jeremy Corbyn’s shadow cabinet.  In  I won my seat from the Lib Dems with a .% swing - the biggest swing to Labour in the country. You would think that would be enough to get me on the ballot and then let Labour members decide whether I’m up to the job. My potential opponent does. Angela Rayner has generously called for some of those who nominated her to switch their vote to me so that we can have a full debate about the future of the party, just as I nominated Jeremy Corbyn, even though I initially supported Andy Burnham, because I thought it was important that his voice was heard. The field of Labour candidates standing for the leadership and deputy leadership, has never been more erse. It remains to be seen whether the candidates that the Parliamentary Labour Partyselect to put before the membership will reflect that.

title: harry meghan megxit
story: NewsopinionThe one thing Harry and Meghan werent expecting: "One wants to come with"As Royals gather for the Sandringham Summit, our columnist Fleet Street Fox wonders whether Megxit is going to snowballShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsopinion" to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMegsie, you wonapost believe it. Granny and Pops have agreed to all our demands. We stay HRH, keep the cops, and theyaposve even signed off on a megabucks deal for banana-flavoured condoms with inspirational messages on them. Thereaposs just one problem. They want to come with us.  The WhatsApp messages that Meghan receives in her Pacic Ocean hideaway following the Sandringham Summit will probably not make the happiest of reading for their recipient. Because what the Duke and Duchess of Sussex donapost seem to have quite figured out is that their Megxit is an awful lot like Brexit. And some of itaposs not possible.Half of them want a massive change because theyaposre unhappy with the way things have been for the past , years. Itaposs all about taking back control, and lots of promises have been made about how great itaposs going to be on the sunlit uplands currently just out of sight, behind that massive constitutional obstacle. The real problem is that, now a vote has been publicly expressed, how much of it can be delivered without smashing the country to smithereens. Some people think itaposs all about race, others that itaposs to do with sovereignty, and thereaposs a lot of speculation and  claims about a thing that nobody in the country will admit they do not have a clue about.A large chunk of it is definitely to do with the Britainaposs long-held, fascinated disdain for all things American. All itaposs really lacking is a bus.Almost certainly, whatever plans are proposed for the Sussexes to consider, will take longer and involve more compromises than expected. You can make your own money, but the palace needs oversight of your contracts. You can live where you like, but choose a tax jurisdiction and stick with it. And the government reserves the right to tell you to shut up.Perhaps those are prices theyaposll decide itaposs wise to pay, for the sake of freedom. They were wise enough to ensure their son Archie had no title. Leaposs much better without one - just ask Zara Tindall.  The Queen will have seen how Brexit was made more damaging simply by dragging on for years. Megxit,it is to go well, must happen quickly - on paper,not in practice.So thereaposs the Queen in one corner, Philip upstairs in bed, hollering and banging his bedpan on the ceiling. A jetlagged Prince Charles on one side, wishing Diana was here to take the blame, and Prince William on the other, desperate to avoid a sibling sideshow that will overshadow his entire reign.And hereaposs Harry, slumped on the sofa just as he did after the strip billiards thing, and the Nazi thing, and the cannabis thing, getting it in the earhole and telling them that this time heaposs had enough and wants out. Harryaposs always wanted out. Finally, he has an excuse. ... I canapost believe youaposve made out this was a surprise. We told you all last year, Harry is saying. You asked me to write down a proposal. I told you it would leak. You insisted, and then it leaked, and now all the Royal reporters are saying youaposre surprised. Truth is, THEYaposRE surprised and youaposre using it against me. Eh  Whataposs that  Canapost hear you, damned thingaposs playing up again, says the Queen, fiddling with a hearing aid she decided would give her some plausible deniability.Weaposd all like out, Harry. We all hate the Press, and we all use it - just as you and your we do, sighs Charles, who has had this argument more than once with every member of his family for  years. Point is, Royals are millionaires who NEED to live like billionaires, or  Richard Branson would seem more royal than us. Weaposre cash-poor, and weaposre not allowed to sell anything.Harry grumbles. Jusapos wanna make money and do good stuff instead of being a lazy arse leeching off the taxpayer infor two daysapos work a week, like the rest of you. How come Iaposm the one in trouble and not the Duke of Dork   BECAUSE YOUaposRE THE ONE ROCKING THE BOAT! Philip is heard bellowing from upstairs. BLOODY I WANT THIS AND THAT AND NOTHINGaposS GOOD ENOUGH. WASNaposT GOOD ENOUGH FOR ME, MY BOY BUT I DAMN WELL PUT UP WITH IT! Told you not to marry an actress, bloody fool thing to do...Harry is outraged. Hang on, Granpa! You reformed the monarchy! TV interviews, a televised coronation, ditching the police guards, driving yourself around London in an environmentally-friendly taxi, the family taking your name - all things they said couldnapost be done! You upturned the Establishment, and now you ARE the Establishment you say I canapost do the same.The Royals all look a bit uncomfortable but the Queen, who has magically heard this bit, says: Weaposve all got things we want to change about the monarchy. But itaposs a constitutional miracle weaposre still here at all. Itaposs a case of softly, softly, catchee monkey. Racist, mutters Harry.  William decides to be big brother. Look, weaposre fine with you leaving. Suits us all, probably. Butyou go now, my children have to put up with more of the attention and we all have to do more work.But Wills,we can make a go of it thereaposll be an exit route for Charlotte and Louis too! bursts out Harry. Theyaposre going to have the same problem as me, as Auntie Margaret - born to be understudies for a role theyaposll never have, and doomed to a le of living off the hospitality of increasingly-rackety friends. Elton John wonapost live forever, you know. The Queen gestures at an aide, who presents Harry with a one-page document from a folder. As you know, one has asked oneaposs advisers for an exit plan. One doesnapost wish to lose you, nor your we, who has managed the astonishing feat of making this family beloved by those parts of the world weaposve literally ridden our horses over. But we canapost have you cocking around with the British constitution. So the plan is, you keep your HRH, strike whatever deals you like, and live where you please. Youaposll still be invited for Christmas and can swan about doing your feminist environmentalism or whatever it is. We want Megxit done quickly and painlessly, so it doesnapost turn into a total saga.  Thereaposs just one catch, the Queen goes on. And itaposs something youaposre probably not expecting.One wants to go with. One wishes to keep oneaposs houses, not Buck House of course, damned thingaposs falling down. But the ponies, the frocks, the right for oneaposs children to pin on medals for things they havenapost done. Colonels will have to colonel their own regiments, Lord Lieutenants can take back control of their own tree-planting ceremonies, Prime Ministers can have sovereignty and see how they bloody like it. One is orf. Iaposm going to call it REXIT. Harry is thunderstruck. But... but... how can you hope to be financially independent Charles is going to sell Cornwall to pay for the coppers, and weaposll all move in with you and Megsie. The Queen gives a mirthless grin. Givenchy say they want me as brand ambassador, and the government says we can help with trade deals. Meghan will be have to do the chlorinated chicken hard-sell, instead. But... the constitution... security... the potential for international embarrassment... stutters Harry.All gone, smiles the Queen, waving a hand. If we all go, those problems cease to exist! Itaposs the only way to make it possible, and besides weaposre all stinking jealous of how much money youaposre going to make. Itaposs a case of oneaposs out, all out!And there you have it. The best form of Brexit the UK could enjoy would beevery other EU state were to Leave as well, agreed to follow the same rules, have custom-free trade and frictionless borders. We could call it the EUK. As for Megxit, the only way to remove the political risks of Royals who leave the tent is for the tent to go with them. For both, people can believe they have wrought a great change, while in reality their lives stay comfortably the same. The Queen would never really resign - but afterthe Good Monday Agreement is good enough, Harry and Meghan will have the right to self-identy as rule-breaking billionaire philanthropists, just so long as they donapost break any rules.

Cash-strapped Michael and Linda Chatha have broken up and decided to raffle off Shrubbery Farm, in Longnor, Shrewbury, after struggling to find a buyer. A £ ticket includes stamp duty and legal fees, with the couple, who have lived at the property  years, hoping to sell , to meet the valuation and cover other fees. They were inspired by another home owner who sold over £ million-worth of tickets for his £,-valued property. Michael said with he and Linda deciding to go their separate ways, they put the cottage on the market last year but failed to find a buyer probably because of the housing market and Brexit. The cottage, just an houraposs drive from Birmingham, also includes The Granary - a self-contained annex, and is estimated to have doubled in value in  years. If , tickets arenapost sold, the lucky winner can instead take away  per cent of the receipts, butthe raffle rakes in more than expected the Chathaaposs will make a big donation to Hope House. It backs onto a th century church and Longnor Hall, with its medieval deer park, which means it is very secluded with almost no neighbours. While a primary school, rated aposOutstandingapos by Ofsted, is within walking distance. Shrewsbury town is a quarter of an hour up the road, and Church Stretton and Ludlow are close, while the Welsh coast is just  minutes down the road. It was more than we could afford but we said you only live once so we stretched ourselves and itaposs been a wonderful home and a great investment. Ludlow, with all its lovely restaurants, is only  minutes away, you can be in Birmingham and Chester within an hour, and within  minutes you can be dipping your feet in the water in Aberdovey in Wales. He added: We know lots of people from Sutton Coldfield and Birmingham would love the idea of living in a country home but the winner could do what they like with it, whether thataposs to rent it out, start an Air BnB or sell it themselves.Itaposs already started to go viral, with lots of people tweeting about it in America. The historic meeting at her private estate will be the first time Harry has met with his grandmother, the Prince of Wales and Duke of Cambridge since the issue engulfed the royal family this week, making headlines around the world. The couple triggered a aposroyal crisisapos by announcing last week they would be stepping back from their duties and spending more time in North America.  It is claimed the couple consulted neither the Queen nor Charles on the announcement, made on Instagram and their own website, a step seen as impertinent and premature. Harry and Meghan said they wanted to carve out a progressive new role for themselves and work to become financially independent. But it was unclear how the couple will become what royal biographers said was akin to being a half royal - and who will pay for their transatlantic lestyles. Meghan has ed to Canada to be with their son Archie after the couple spent six weeks in the country in late .  The duchess flew to Canada a few days ago where the family spent an extended festive break in the province of British Columbia. It is thought William will be travelling to the estate in Norfolk from his Kensington Palace apartment and Harry from Frogmore Cottage near Windsor Castle. Charles was in Oman to attend a condolence ceremony following the death of Sultan Qaboos bin Said al Said, and was due to travel back to the UK on Sunday evening. The Queen attended church at Sandringham on Sunday where wellwishers expressed sympathy for her, and clapped as she left, with some members of the public saying that Harry and Meghan should not receive any more taxpayersapos money.  The monarch was pictured arriving for the service wearing a hearing aid for what is believed to be the first time in public. Harry and Meghan are said to have left the Queen feeling hurt by their bombshell announcement that they plan to step back as senior royals, become financially independent and split their time between the UK and North America. There are a range of issues to be discussed today, and it is likely the royals will try to come to some agreement before the meeting ends to stop the immediate crisis causing lasting damage to the monarchy. Harry and Meghanaposs statement - and a new official Sussexroyal website - have thrown up important questions about funding for the coupleaposs round-the-clock security, media access to their royal events and how they will pay for their future lestyles.  Other important issues to resolve include who will pay for the substantial security cost of protecting the couple and their baby sonthey spend large portions of the year in Canada and possibly America. It is not known what time the family plan to meet, how long the summit is expected to last or whether the entire day has been set aside to find a solution. Before the meeting, the royals will be given written proposals produced by their offices and others, including relevant government departments from the UK and Canada, where it is thought Harry and Meghan will establish a second home.

Those attending the meeting, which is expected to take place this morning, include the Queen, Prince Charles, William and Harry. Meghan is also likely to be dialling in from Canada at am local time. Key issues for the future of Meghan and Harryaposs relationship with the Royal Family will be discussed after last weekaposs sensational announcement that they intend to aposstep backapos as senior royals. It is possible that nothing will be resolved today and there are reports that the so-called aposabdicationapos of the young royal couple could take months. All three of William, Charles and the Queen are expected to warn that there are signicant obstacles to be overcome before Harry and Meghan can make their move. Important questions thrown up by Harry and Meghanaposs new website are likely to be central to discussions. Funding for the coupleaposs round-the-clock security, media access to their royal events and how they will pay for their future lestyles will be very important. A vital issue to resolve includes who will pay for the substantial security cost of protecting the couple and their baby sonthey spend large portions of the year in Canada and possibly the US. At the meeting, it is understood Harry will be presented with documents put together following talks with the tax authorities in the UK and Canada, after the couple said they wish to be aposfinancially independentapos and seek to make their own money away from royal le. The Duke and Duchess potentially face a aposdouble taxapos on commercial income and bills running into the millions from numerous authorities, reports the Mail Online .  And with Canada requiring residents and certain property owners to pay income tax on global earnings, in a similar way to the UK, Harry could be forced to give up his UK residency or limit his time in Canada. Harry and Meghan have said the Sovereign Grant makes up just five per cent of their income and is only used for official office expenses and that they intend to give it up as they aim to become financially independent. But with hundreds of thousands still likely to be spent from public money each year for official travel abroad, this will likely be a key issue at the meeting. The Sussexesapos website states that  per cent of their annual funding comes from the Duchy of Cornwall, the Prince of Wales’s private estate, estimated at around £.million. It is likely to be discussed whether Charles is willing to continue to allow this. It has been reported they may be keen to make promotional deals abroad to allow for financial independence, but these may not be compatible with their royal work. Also, the Queen owns their Windsor home Frogmore Cottage , which was renovated to the cost of £.m recently, but surveys suggest the public may not be keen for them to retain it. Itaposs possible that the financially independent royal couple may be required to pay some form of rent to stay there.  Although reportedly left hurt by Harry and Meghanaposs actions, the Queen is not given to rash decisions, and will be approaching the talks in a calm and pragmatic way. One question thrown up is whether the couple will keep their HRH titles but it is thought senior royals are not keen on stripping them of the status. Also, the couple are unlikely to surrender their titles as their aposSussexRoyalapos brand is built on them. Heir-to-the-throne Prince Charles is the future king and currently bankrolls Harry and Meghanaposs public duties through his £ million-a-year Duchy of Cornwall income. The extent to which this will continue seems likely to crop up. The prince is a caring, sensitive soul, and is said to be furious at how Harry and Meghan have handled the situation. He is committed to his royal duty, but will also want his youngest son, who endured the loss of his mother Diana, Princess of Wales, when he was only , and Meghan to be happy. The talks also come amid repeated reports of a falling out between Harry and William. Older brother William, who was said to be incandescent with rage at the Sussexesapos actions, is a future king, and his position within the royal family is vastly dferent from sixth-in-line Harry, who has moved steadily down the line of succession and has to carve out his own role. In his ITV interview on a tour of Africa, Harry conceded that he and William aposhave good days and bad daysapos and are aposon dferent pathsapos. What future working relationship the two princes have will be interesting to see after Harry takes his step back.  For Meghan and Harry, their priorities will be ensuring a smooth retreat from royal le that enables them to fulfil their work with charities and in Africa on the causes that interest them. The Duke and Duchess said in their statement, they want to carve out a progressive new role, and continue to collaborate with the Queen. How their new commercial work ties in with this collaboration with the royal family could be determined by todayaposs talks.  Meghan may have flown back to Canada, but she will likely be dialling into the meeting as the proposals on offer are discussed. The intelligent, driven American former actress, who is just  months into her royal le, will be focused on the work she and Harry are keen to do.  Speaking about coping with intense tabloid interest, the Duchess has said: Itaposs not enough to just survive something, thataposs not the point of le. You have got to thrive.
